description: Borrowed from Late Latin systēmaticus, from Koine Greek συστηματικός (sustēmatikós), from σύστημᾰ (sústēma, “a composite; system”) +‎ -ῐκός (-ikós, adjective suffix). Cognate with French systématique and Italian sistematico. By surface analysis, system +‎ -atic.

adjectives.description: systematic (comparative more systematic, superlative most systematic)

entries.meaning: Carried out according to a planned, ordered procedure.
Treating an object as a system or coherent whole.
examples: the systematic study of religious beliefs

entries.meaning: (taxonomy) Of or relating to taxonomic classification.
(chemistry) Of, relating to, or in accordance with generally recognized conventions for the naming of chemicals.
(archaic or academic) Of, relating to, or being a system.

adverbs.description: systematic (comparative more systematic, superlative most systematic)
